description: Dive into "Romantic Escapes in Enchanting Ayutthaya" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Romantic Escapes in Enchanting Ayutthaya

places.generalDescription: Wat Phanan Choeng Worawihan, also known as the temple of the seated Buddha, is a historic and ornate temple complex located by the river. Dating back to before the founding of the Ayutthaya Kingdom, it has survived fires and been renovated over time. The main hall houses an impressive 19-meter tall sitting Buddha statue that attracts both locals and visitors.

sources.snippet: Wat Panan Choeng is a Buddhist temple on the east bank of the Chao Phraya River, its overriding focus the gigantic golden Buddha figure posing majestically on high. It is 19 metres (62ft) high, 14 metres (46ft) wide, and revered throughout the region as sacred for mariners. Built in 1324, this is one of the oldest (not to mention largest and most worshipped) Buddha statues in Thailand, and they say it shed tears when the Burmese burnt Ayutthaya down in 1767.
sources.shortName: The Top 19 Things To Do In Ayutthaya, Thailand

sources.snippet: Wat Phanan Choeng is a spectacular Buddhist temple in the Historical Park of Ayutthaya. It differs from the other nearby temples in that it is a living monastery that still follows the doctrine of Buddhist faith, with people worshipping the statue of the sitting Buddha. It is most known for an enormous gilded statue of Lord Buddha in the traditional Mara or sitting posture.
sources.shortName: 52 Things to do in Ayutthaya Thailand 2025

sources.snippet: Wat Phanan Choeng is a historical gem in Ayutthaya because the history of this temple dates back to 1324. Especially worth seeing the imposing, cross-legged sitting Buddha statue, which is located directly inside the temple. This impressive golden statue is about 19 meters high and thus one of the largest Buddha statues of Thailand.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Amazing Things to Do in Ayutthaya (Thailand)

sources.snippet: A massive (19 meters high) Buddha statue where you‚Äôll encounter many praying locals. Take off your shoes and walk around the Buddha statue.
sources.shortName: Ayutthaya, Thailand 2018 ‚òÄ Destination Guide

places.name: Wat Phanan Choeng Worawihan

reviews.text:
We went there as a part of a private tour of four ayutthaya temples. This was the first one.

One thing I would like to highlight is when we reached there we didn't find instructions in English. Most of the instructions are in thai language.

After going around a bit, we figured where the main temple was, and we went inside.

The entry fee is 20 baht per person.

The buddha statue is very big and around main temple there are small small temples that you can visit.
This place is beautiful. It is a very old temple that has been with Ayutthaya Province. It is located next to a large river. Many people come to make merit here. There is a lot of parking space.
We had a great experience visiting this old monastry. A bonus witnessing a new monk celebration. It houses Thailand's largest ancient Buddha image. Admission fee is 20 Baht. Children are free.

places.address: 8HVH+MG9, ‡∏ï‡∏≥‡∏ö‡∏• ‡∏Ñ‡∏•‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏™‡∏ß‡∏ô‡∏û‡∏•‡∏π Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya District, Chang Wat Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya 13000, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Wat Yai Chai Mongkhon is a restored Buddhist temple in Ayutthaya, featuring stupas and a huge reclining Buddha along with smaller seated ones in a row. The temple was built during the 14th century and is the largest and most important in Ayutthaya. It houses two large chedis built in classic Ayutthaya style, influenced by Ceylon architecture.

sources.snippet: Not all Ayutthaya‚Äôs temples are in sorry states of disrepair. Wat Yai Chaimongkol (the Temple of Auspicious Victory) is a working monastery, complete with a 20th Century viharn (prayer hall) and reclining Buddha remodelled from older structures. The towering central chedi echoes the summit of Mount Meru, a sacred, mythical peak.
sources.shortName: The Top 19 Things To Do In Ayutthaya, Thailand

sources.snippet: Known for being another Ayutthaya‚Äôs best-preserved temples, the visit to Wat Yai Chai Mongkol is one of the most essential places to see in Ayutthaya since it is also one of the most beautiful and magical temples in this area of ‚Äã‚Äã Thailand. Wat Yai Chai Mongkol was built in 1357 by King U-Thong, it is visible from many parts of the city for its large chedi, over 62 meters, for which almost 30,000 tons of bricks were used in its construction. But in addition to this chedi, what really gives this temple a special aspect is the sculpture of an incredible Buddha lying on its back, that of dozens of Buddhas that are usually covered with yellow robes, giving this place a truly magical appearance.
sources.shortName: 8 Must-Visit Temples in Ayutthaya, Thailand

sources.snippet: On the eastern outskirts of Ayutthaya stands the exceptionally striking Wat Yai Chai Mongkol (or Mongkhon), its huge chedi rising from a square base surrounded by four smaller chedis. One of its most notable features is the massive reclining Buddha near the entrance. The wat, built in 1357 under King U Thong, was assigned to monks of a particularly strict order trained in Sri Lanka, members of which still live there.
sources.shortName: 13 Top-Rated Tourist Attractions in Ayutthaya

sources.snippet: The temple Wat Yai Chai Mongkhon is one of the most beautiful places to visit in Ayutthaya. This gigantic complex from the year 1357 is located on the outskirts of the city and is also a popular stop on day tours and roundtrips. Particularly impressive is the approximately 8 meter high Chedi, which was made of 28,144 tons of stones and is surrounded by 4 smaller Chedis.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Amazing Things to Do in Ayutthaya (Thailand)

sources.snippet: Unlike the other temples I‚Äôve visited, Wat Yai Chai Mongkhon isn‚Äôt within the magical/ feng shui rich island of Ayutthaya. Rather, it is located southeast, or about a 5-minute drive, from the train station. Constructed during the reign of King U-Thong, Wat Yai Chai Mongkhon is known for its huge chedi/ stupa, which has ‚Äòa wishing well‚Äô within.
sources.shortName: One Day in Ayutthaya

sources.snippet: Wat Yai Chaimongkon is located near the main Ayutthaya ruins and a short distance from the walls of Ayutthaya. It is famed for an impressively large statue of the Reclining Buddha inside the temple compound. Built by King U Thong (Ayutthaya‚Äôs first ruler) in 1357, the temple is also known as "Chao Phaya Thai Temple" and has a large Chedi...
sources.shortName: Attractions in

sources.snippet: Wat Yai Chai Mongkhon also referred to as the Mongkhon is one of the primary temples in Ayutthaya. This temple has been restored many times since its construction during the 14th century. Although found to be partially ruined, Wat Yai Chai Mongkhon is functioning to date, with several monks housed within the building.
sources.shortName: 52 Things to do in Ayutthaya Thailand 2025

sources.snippet: The gigantic main stupa of this temple is visible from most parts of the city. Constructed in 1357, it is one of the oldest temples of the Ayutthaya Kingdom. Spend half an hour or so strolling the grounds and climbing up the stupa stairs for photographic proof of how big the stupa is.
sources.shortName: Tour of Ayutthaya Temples: A 2-Day Cultural Itinerary

sources.snippet: A lively and varied temple complex with hundreds of Buddha statues lined up next to each other. The best place in Ayutthaya to take some nice pictures.
sources.shortName: Ayutthaya, Thailand 2018 ‚òÄ Destination Guide

places.name: ‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏î‡πÉ‡∏´‡∏ç‡πà‡∏ä‡∏±‡∏¢‡∏°‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏•‡∏ß‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏´‡∏≤‡∏£

reviews.text: Wat Yai Chai Mongkhon, while not among the largest temples, possesses a unique beauty, both refined and captivating. The most striking feature is the magnificent main chedi, dominating the temple grounds. Its architecture exudes an ancient and majestic aura, inspiring awe in all who behold it. Even more exciting is the opportunity to climb inside the chedi. From the top, the panoramic view of the surrounding landscape unfolds like a breathtaking painting. It's a memorable experience and a must-do when visiting Wat Yai Chai Mongkhon. The harmonious blend of unique architecture and stunning natural scenery creates an irresistible charm for this temple.

This place is very beautiful. The pagoda is very big. It is an old temple. There is a big reclining Buddha and a small reclining Buddha. It is charming, shady, and peaceful. Many people come here. There is a lot of parking. There are many restaurants outside the temple. I like this place.

Famous Temple in Ayutthaya, Thailand
üôèüèª It is believed that the blessings made by the great Buddha will come true.

No admission fee , Parking lot

The weather is quite hot, so bringing a hat or a small fan umbrella will help make it smoother.

places.generalDescription: The Wat Kasattrathirat temple is an active Buddhist temple used by the clergy. The complex has a history that dating back all the way to the 15th century and features buildings that are relatively modern, but it is well maintained. The landscaping is 5-star and must be seen, as well as the peacefulness of the place. There is also a pier where you can feed fish.

sources.snippet: Wat Kasatrathirat Worawihan is an active monastery used by the Buddhist clergy. While most of the buildings of the complex are relatively modern, it has a history that dating back all the way to the 15th century. Destroyed by attacks, it has been restored multiple times.
sources.shortName: 52 Things to do in Ayutthaya Thailand 2025

places.name: Wat Kasattrathirat Worawihan

reviews.text: A temple near in Phranakorn Sri Ayuddhaya province. I went there on weekday and not many people. I pay respect to the monk and donate for the temple. It's a beautiful and clean temple.

Situated in the outer ring of Ayutthaya city. It is beside by the river, opposite of Chedi Phra Si Suriyothai. According the characteristic of its prang, it is believed that the temple was built in the Sukhothai period, founded in B.E. 2200. It was totally destroyed during the Burmese invasion. The Burmese used this temple as a military base to fire cannon across the river onto the city. The temple was built up again during the time of King Rama I. Prince Isranurak, King Rama Is nephew, restored it under its new name. Under his renovations, the pagoda were added inside the main prangs niches (in older periods this would have been a Buddha image). It is a beautiful arrangement of buildings at the river with the principal Buddha image inside the Ubosot.

Wat Kasattrathirat Worawihan is the 3 rd class of royal temple ( 2 nd grade which called Worawihan) is located at the edge of Chao Phraya River on west bank off the city island, a large field nearby called ‚Äú Thung Prachet‚Äù, Tambon Ban Pom, Amphoe Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya, Chang Wat Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya, north of the road number 3263( road heading to Supanburi. The year of establishing this temple is uncertain, assumed to be the reign of King Phra Thi Nang Suriya in A.D.1760( B.E.2303).In A.D. 1767 ( B.E. 2310), the General of Burmese armies (Posuphla) sent soldiers to establish a stronghold at Ban Pom as the village of the Fort, so they could use cannons fired at the Ayutthaya city, formerly this temple called ‚Äú Wat Kasatra‚Äù or ‚Äú Wat Kasatraram‚Äù, was destroyed many parts burned to ashes and deserted, later on this temple had been through renovation 2times, the first renovation was during A.D. 1782-1809, in the reign of the Ratanakosin period by King Rama 1's nephew ( Prince Khrom Khun Isranurak), after restoration this temple ‚Äòs name was changed from ‚Äú Wat Kasatra‚Äù to ‚Äú Wat Kasatrathirat‚Äù, the second renovation was during the reign of King Rama 4, Khom Mun Ayulyalaksa Sombat( Prince Urai ) supervised, Pra Kru Winyanuwattikun constructed more building and chapel and completely finished in A.D. 1879, totally 14 years, King Rama 5 named ‚Äú Wat Kasattrathirat Worawihan ‚Äú, this is active temple, nowadays.

places.address: 15, Ban Pom, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya District, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya 13000, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Wat Phukhao Thong is a Buddhist temple with a 50-meter-high chedi that was founded in 1569 and restored in the 18th century. The all-white Chedi Phu Khao Thong stands out in an empty field, serving as a stunning landmark visible from afar.

sources.snippet: This enormous chedi towers over the landscape like a giant white bell, topped with a gold ball worth more than ¬£100,000. It was built on top of an older structure by Ayutthaya‚Äôs most celebrated king, Naresuan, who reigned between 1590 and 1605. His statue, mounted on a horse, can be found in the grounds.
sources.shortName: The Top 19 Things To Do In Ayutthaya, Thailand

sources.snippet: A one-of-a-kind temple, the Wat Phu Khao Thong or 'Monastery of the Golden Mount' located in Ayutthaya is unique for the diversity it offers to its viewers!. Take the stairs to the top, and bask in the environs of the temple, with views of surrounding mosques, paddy fields, kampongs and the dynamic diasporic diversity that Ayutthaya has to offer. The temple is attached to a small monastery.
sources.shortName: 52 Things to do in Ayutthaya Thailand 2025

sources.snippet: This original Mon-style chedi sits outside the historical park, away from the busy crowds and amid green rice paddies. For the best views of the peaceful surroundings, visitors can climb halfway up the chedi to a platform. The current 50-meter-tall building dates back to 1569 and has been modified over the centuries to incorporate both Thai and Burmese details.
sources.shortName: 13 Top-Rated Tourist Attractions in Ayutthaya

sources.snippet: Wat Phu Khao Thong is often called "Golden Mount Pagoda" and was built in 1387. The site originally housed a large Mon-style Chedi built by King Hongsawadi of Burma to commemorate his victory in Ayutthaya in 1569. During restoration during the reign of King Boromakot a new Thai-style Chedi was built on the base of the former Chedi.
sources.shortName: Attractions in

sources.snippet: A post shared by AON & LAN üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà‚É§ Travel Couple (@deeristravelling). When mentioning the best and beautiful temples to visit in Ayutthaya Wat Phu Khao Thong can‚Äôt be omitted. Wat Phu Khao Thong also is known as the Golden Mountain Monastery: This monastery was built by King Ramesuan in 1395.
sources.shortName: 8 Must-Visit Temples in Ayutthaya, Thailand

sources.snippet: The Wat Phu Khao Thong, also known as the White Temple, is one of Ayutthaya‚Äôs best kept insider tips. This snow-white temple is located about two kilometers outside the old town and is not as busy as other temples in the center. It was built as early as 1387.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Amazing Things to Do in Ayutthaya (Thailand)

sources.snippet: An impressively large Chedi tower located about two kilometers north-west of the city. Climb the temple and enjoy the view of the countryside.
sources.shortName: Ayutthaya, Thailand 2018 ‚òÄ Destination Guide

places.name: ‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏î‡∏†‡∏π‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏≠‡∏á

reviews.text:
The temple here is at the middle at the rice field along day way to Ayutthaya city.

Good to see the history and how their kept the infrastructure and structure around. My brother and myself really enjoyed the history.

Facility is complete for all tourists.
Amazing and beautiful Wat, no ticket needed to enter here, there is a lotus pond nearby where you might find fully bloomed lotus flower.

After traveling for almost 2 days by road from Penang we finally make it to Wat Phu Khao Thong, also known as the "Golden Mount,"  a captivating temple located approximately 3 km northwest of Ayutthaya's city center. The temple was originally established in 1387 by King Ramesuan of the Ayutthaya Kingdom. However in 1569,  Ayutthaya falls into the Burmese's hand, where King Bayinnaung of Bago commissioned The construction of this tempke unfortunately it was never compketed
.
If you happen to be in Ayutthaya, you got to see this unique serene historical site that offers ancient architectural beauty, making it hard to resist.

üèõÔ∏è Architectural Design
The chedi stands approximately 50 meters tall and showcases a harmonious blend of Mon-Burmese and Thai architectural styles. Its square base with indented corners supports a towering spire, reflecting the fusion of cultural influences over time. Visitors can ascend to a midway platform, offering panoramic views of the surrounding rice fields and the city of Ayutthaya.

Distance from Ayutthaya City Center is approximately 3 km northwest. You can commute there either ride a Tuk-Tuk, or ride a bicycle - for the adventurous scenic route, hire a car or Taxi or public transport to easily access to the temple.

üåü What you will find
1. Golden Ball -
a golden ball weighing approximately 2.5 kgs was placed atop the chedi to commemorate 2,500 years of Buddhism 2. Buddha Footprint -
The temple houses a revered Buddha footprint, attracting pilgrims and visitors alike.
3. Panoramic Views -
The elevated platform provides breathtaking vistas of Ayutthaya's landscape, ideal for photography and reflection.

This temple stands as a testament to Ayutthaya's rich history and cultural resilience and a profound glimpse into Thailand's spiritual heritage.

........................

If you find this article useful, give me a Like for motivation.

places.address: 153 9G9Q+JWG, Phu Khao Thong, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya District, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya 13000, Thailand

sources.snippet: There is no exact date to when this reclining Buddha was built but it was restored in 1954. Measuring 42 meters long, this is something different to the usual ruins around this area. Around the Buddha are 24 octagon-shaped pillars which could suggest that this Buddha was encased by a Vihara (a Buddhist monastery).
sources.shortName: Things to do in Ayutthaya Thailand

places.name: Reclining Buddha Sai Yat - Phra Buddha Sai Yat

reviews.text:
Visiting Phra Buddha Sai Yat (The Reclining Buddha) was a truly mesmerizing experience. The sheer size and elegance of the reclining Buddha statue left me in awe. At 37 meters long, this statue is not only massive but also beautifully detailed. The peaceful expression on the Buddha's face, paired with the serene surroundings of the temple, creates a calming atmosphere that allows you to take in the spiritual significance of the place.

What I found particularly interesting was how the reclining Buddha symbolizes the Buddha's final moments before attaining Nirvana, a powerful representation of peace and enlightenment. The temple is well-maintained, and the staff and monks are incredibly welcoming, making the visit even more memorable. Whether you're here for spiritual reasons or to admire the incredible craftsmanship, Phra Buddha Sai Yat is a must-see when visiting Ayutthaya.

Highly recommended for anyone looking to explore the cultural and spiritual history of Thailand!

We visited Wat Lokayasutharam, which is famous for its Reclining Buddha. Since it is located outdoors and deterioration seems to be progressing, the Reclining Buddha had been repainted in a bright yellow color. It is said to be the second-largest Reclining Buddha in Thailand, after the one at Wat Pho.

I visited the Reclining Buddha at Wat Lokayasutharam, and it's absolutely stunning! This massive golden-yellow Buddha, peacefully lying at 42 meters long, is such a calming sight. The whole area feels so serene and full of history. It was also renewed recently and I belive still under going maintainance modez

places.address: 9H42+6WP, Pratu Chai Sub-district, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya District, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya 13000, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Wihan Phra Mongkhon Bophit is a bustling and contemporary temple located just 4 km from the city center of Ayutthaya. It is renowned for housing a colossal, gilded statue of the seated Buddha, which is one of the largest in Thailand. The temple compound, nestled within the historical park of Ayutthaya near the Grand Palace, attracts numerous visitors due to its rich historical significance.

sources.snippet: A visit to the Wihan Phra Mongkhon Bophit is certainly one of the best things to do in Ayutthaya. The ultimate gem and the most important attraction inside the temple complex is the approximately 12.5 meter high bronze Buddha, one of the largest golden Buddha statues in Thailand. It dates back to the early era of the Ayutthaya Empire, from the 14th ‚Äì 15th centuries, but was gilded much later, in 1991 on the occasion of the Thai King‚Äôs birthday.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Amazing Things to Do in Ayutthaya (Thailand)

sources.snippet: Nestled in the historical park of Ayutthaya close to the Grand Palace, Wihan Phra Mongkhon Bophit is a temple compound that magnetizes hordes of visitors with a compelling historical statue. It is famous for encompassing one of the biggest Buddha statues in Thailand and the oldest Buddha statue in Ayutthaya city - a 17-metre tall bronze gilded statue, said to be carved by the King Chairachathirat. himself, after the death of his son.
sources.shortName: 52 Things to do in Ayutthaya Thailand 2025

sources.snippet: A stunning religious site, Wihan Phra Mongkhon Bophit is whre you can find one of the most detailed bronze Buddha statues in the world. Here, the Buddha image has lap measurement of 9.55 meters. The statue stands at a height of 12.45 meters and features exceptional level of detail.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Ayutthaya, Tourist Places & Attractions

places.name: Wiharn Phra Mongkhon Bophit

reviews.text:
Really enjoyed stopping by. It's super easy to visit if you're already exploring the nearby ruins. Unfortunately, the giant Buddha was under restoration when we visited, so we missed that üôçüèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è but I can imagine it'll look amazing once it's done.
The architecture is beautiful and it was a nice break from the ruins and a lovely place to just take it all in.

Very good temple. Many people are coming for blessing with many things. Wheel chair accessible and chairs are there. Many places to wash your hand with soaps etc. toilet facilities available a. Near it refreshing drinking available. Not so crowded.
2025 February 6

It is located next to Wat Phra Sri Sanphet and is easily recognizable as a huge and beautiful temple. There are also old photos inside the temple, so it is quite interesting to see how they were restored. By the way, the main Buddha statue is currently being restored.

places.generalDescription: The Wat Pichai Songkram Buddhist Temple is a beautiful and historic monastery that dates back to the 14th century. Several monks reside here even today, and the temple is a popular tourist attraction. The grounds are lined with beautiful trees and gardens, and the riverbank location is lovely.

sources.snippet: Located on the banks of the Pa Sak River Wat Pichai Songkram is a beautiful Buddhist monastery that dates back to the 14th century. Several monks reside here even today. The current name ‚ÄòWat Pichai Songkram‚Äô meaning ‚ÄòTemple of War Victory‚Äô was bestowed on this monastery in honour of King Taskin and his troops, who won over the Burmese invaders.
sources.shortName: 52 Things to do in Ayutthaya Thailand 2025

places.name: Wat Pichai Songkram

reviews.text: Beautiful temple just at the riverfront. Very nicely decorated all over the temple area with a lot of statues and rocks. It's about 5 min from the train station so very easy to go to. I would definitely recommend to go see this fantastic area

Amazingly beautiful Buddhist temple, just a 5 minute walking distance from the trainstation.
Free entrance.
Very quiet, hardly any other people.
Nice temple on the river near train station

sources.snippet: Take a moonlit stroll through Odaiba, a seaside district filled with futuristic architecture and beautiful waterfront views ‚Äî located about a 15-minute drive from establishments like Oakwood Residence Azabujyuban Tokyo, where you can find plush Tokyo one bedroom apartments. The Rainbow Bridge twinkling in the distance and the serene waterfront are guaranteed to elevate your date.

It's still a small night market but a bit disappointing

places.generalDescription: Ayutthaya Tours Thailand offers a variety of tour options including cycle, boat, train, tuk tuk and coach tours. These day trips from Bangkok are convenient for those with limited time. The tours come with knowledgeable guides who provide insights into the historical sites and rich culture of Ayutthaya. Visitors have praised the well-organized and unforgettable experiences offered by Ayutthaya Tours, making it highly recommended for anyone looking to explore the ancient city's beauty and history.

sources.snippet: Honestly, going by tour saves you time, is convenient, and comes with a guide. I had only one day and wanted to see and learn as much as possible from Ayutthaya. The guide was knowledgeable about the various sites we‚Äôve visited, and I thought the day was well-spent!
sources.shortName: One Day in Ayutthaya

sources.snippet: Although there are no direct boat services to Ayutthaya, it is possible to take a river cruise from Bangkok to Bang Pa-In and then take a taxi or bus to Ayutthaya. This can be a scenic way to travel and takes around 3-4 hours depending on the cruise.
sources.shortName: Tripper - Guide - A romantic day trip to Ayutthaya, Thailand

places.name: Ayutthaya Tour Thailand (Heritage Boat Tour)

reviews.text: Tour was amazing! Lucky was very informative about everywhere we went too. The dinner was delicious and the dancer on the boat after was amazing!! I'd definitely recommend.
Great day on the river, sunset over temples, photography highlights - good minivan with aircon, right amount of time to stop at each spot! Thank you for Johnny and Captain Jack for a great tour!

Ayutthaya Tours organised by Sunday Leisure tours was a fantastic experience. The timing for sunset tour was perfect.
A special nostalgic experience was the local traditional Dance by Mook on the boat.
Really aowesome. Would highly recommend.

places.address: 23, 28, Tha Wasukri, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya District, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya 13000, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Krungsri River Hotel is a centrally located accommodation in Ayutthaya, offering airy quarters and a bright ambiance. The hotel features an Italian eatery with live music, as well as amenities such as bowling and a spa. Guests can take advantage of the outdoor pool, sauna, and fitness center for recreational activities. The hotel also offers complimentary wireless internet access, concierge services, and a reception hall.

sources.snippet: With its marble bathrooms, outdoor pool and riverside terrace for dining and drinking, the Krungsri River Hotel makes for a welcome change to the usual guesthouses that are all over the city of Ayutthaya. Whilst it may be a little further out from the temples, it makes up for it with its luxurious feel and features. Bathrooms are decked out with a marble finish and feature decadent bathtub; its suites are brimming with elegance thanks to the comfy sofas and tall windows and its scenic riverside terrace offers a sense of peace, clarity and romance that other hotels can‚Äôt match.
sources.shortName: The Best Places To Stay In Ayutthaya, Thailand

places.name: Krungsri River Hotel

reviews.text: Great riverside hotel. I think it has been refurbished as it is really clean and modern. Rooms are great and the swimming pool is excellent as is the gym. There are 3 restaurants and they have live music. For value for money it cannot be beaten

Good quality hotel. Spotless clean, functional rooms. No view for me. The hotel has more of a business feel to it than tourist. Lovely pool particularly for watching the sunset - though absolutely freezing! Good gym too. Good breakfast. The immediate area around the hotel has nothing to offer that I could see, but I didn't spend much time in the hotel so I could've missed something. Recommended.

having stayed at over 100 thai hotels like this over the past 4 years, this is a fair review. pool good, breakfast good, staff ok. cleaning staff excellent , front desk indifferent. if you stay in room 515, you may have problems. we had to have our safe opened FIVE times because it didn't work. they offered another  room after the third time , so we pack all our things up and were then taken to a far worse room, so we stayed in the original. then we had to unpack...again! the location is isolated from the historic sites and the wonderful night market. i would not recommend this hotel. decent bed and great showers. can be noisy.

places.address: 27/2 ‡∏´‡∏°‡∏π‡πà‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà11 Rojana Rd, Kamang, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya District, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya 13000, Thailand
